title: rishi-sunaks-latest-fiscal-bazooka-mean-self-employed
story: The Chancellor has unveiled new measures designed to help support the countryrsquos legion of non-staff workers.ndash Whatrsquos the big announcement, then It was the news that self-employed workers and freelancers had been eagerly anticipating ndash that the new support package for self-employed people would match that of permanent staff in covering % of average earnings over the past three years. They would need to demonstrate this by presenting three yearsrsquo worth of accounts.ndash Was the Government under pressure to deliver A euphoric lsquoyesrsquo. Many of the countryrsquos millions of self-employed people were left in limbo after their work dried up in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. The breadth of those affected was noted by Chancellor Rishi Sunak as he made the announcement, name-checking workers as erse as musicians, taxi drivers, tradesmen and hairdressers among those affected. Also, there was a need to act ndash the longer the lockdown, and the longer self-employed people are left at home rather than working, the more this will cost the Government.ndash Sounds promising. What about people not covered by the scheme Mr Sunak said the scheme covered % of self-employed people for whom the majority of their earnings come from that work. He said the remaining % had average annual earnings of more than pound, per year, so would not be covered by the scheme. He described this as ldquoreasonable, proportionate and fair.ndash He mentioned Universal Credit ndash what is this Irsquom proud of what wersquove done so far, but I know that many self-employed people are deeply anxious about the support available for them.So to support those who work for themselves, today I am announcing a new Self-Employed Income Support Scheme. pic wJQZzNFOCHmdash Rishi SunakMarch , The Department for Work and Pensionshas been inundated with more than half a million new applications for the controversial welfare reform in the last week, which replaced benefits such as income support and job seekerrsquos allowance.ndash So will self-employed people in immediate need for Universal Credit be able to get an advance credit to tide them over Yes. Mr Sunak said those in need would be able to get an advanced payment ldquoalmost immediately so would not have to wait for  days. The Chancellor said that extra resources were being put into local authorities to help those who are most vulnerable to pay for things such as council tax bills.ndash What about people who have only entered the self-employment workforce and may not have the full three yearsrsquo worth of accounts vw,vw,px, px"Chancellor Rishi Sunak told self-employed people lsquoyou have not been forgottenrsquo during a press conference on Thursday evening Mr Sunak said the Government would ldquolook at whatever they do have in that case. However, he said it would be dficult to provide that support where people had been in self-employment for less than a year, citing how the scheme would be more susceptible to fraud.ndash So this scheme has broadly been welcomed Itrsquos a tonic for those worried about their futures. However, the fact they will have to wait until June to claim the support will do little to soothe some concerns..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: What does Rishi Sunak us latest fiscal bazooka mean for the self-employed

title: scottish-finance-secretary-calls-urgency-new-self-employed-support
story: Scotlandrsquos Finance Secretary has said she has ldquoserious concerns about the wait self-employed people face to access new UK Government support.Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced plans for grants covering % of a self-employed workerrsquos average monthly profit up to pound, to help boost finances during the coronavirus outbreak.However, the new scheme may not be available to June, prompting criticism of the waiting times facing Scotlandrsquos self-employed, which official figures put at ,.Scottish finance secretary Kate Forbes said: ldquoAlong with a range of organisations and hundreds of thousands of self-employed people across Scotland, we have been calling on the UK Government to introduce a package of measures for the self-employed similar to the support they announced for employees.ldquoI am pleased to see this announcement today and I recognise the dficulties in administering the system, but I have serious concerns about how long people will have to wait for this much-needed support.ldquoMany self-employed people are on low incomes with bills to pay and families to feed, and they cannot afford to wait until June for this vital support.ldquoMore urgency is required whether through speeding up payments or the benefits system.Both the Scottish Greens and the SNP reiterated calls for the introduction of a universal basic income to help those struggling financially during the Covid- pandemic.Meanwhile, the Scottish Liberal Democrats were among those who welcomed the support package but expressed concerns over potentially y waits as did the Scottish Trades Union Congress .Rozanne Foyer, STUC general secretary designate, said: ldquoThis is a largely welcome intervention which will provide relief for many, though there is still a signicant potential time delay between now and likely payment time.ldquoThis could cause real hardship. We need to get this going and more quickly than the Chancellor suggested.Unions stand ready to help make this happen.Liz Cameron, Scottish Chambers of Commerce chief executive, stressed the grants ldquomust flow quickly to support those eligible in Scotland, adding: ldquoIn the main, this support scheme will be a great relief to the vast bulk of the , self-employed people in Scotland who are essential to the fabric of our economy particularly in rural areas.vw,vw,px, px"Scottish Secretary Alister Jack praised the grants announcement Scottish Secretary Alister Jack said: ldquoTodayrsquos announcement means that people who work for themselves ndash the entrepreneurs who drive innovation and economic growth ndash will have the very best chance of picking up their businesses once this current crisis is over.ldquoWe are undoubtedly facing incredibly dficult times. But the UK Government is doing everything possible to support iniduals, businesses, and communities. And I know all of us will also be doing what we can to support family, friends and neighbours. Together, we will get through this..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Scottish Finance Secretary calls for urgency over new self-employed support

title: space-force-launches-first-mission-amid-virus-precautions
story: The newly-established US Space Force has launched its first national security satellite, with a leaner staff because of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoNothing stops the space launch mission, the th Space Wing tweeted from Cape Canaveral.The one billion US dollars satellite is the sixth and final one in the US militaryrsquos Advanced Extremely High Frequency series.Upgraded from the older Milstar satellites, the constellation has provided secure communication from , miles above the Earth for nearly a decade.On March , #AEHFwas hoisted atop the #AtlasVrocket for this Thursdayrsquos launch to complete the @SpaceForceDoDAEHF satellite constellation.Learn more in our blog: https:t.co bdWrJGrgrpic inwZIVhRmdash ULAMarch , A powerful Atlas V rocket hoisted the , kilogram satellite. The new Space Force seal adorned the United Launch Alliance rocket.The Space Force officially became a new branch of the US military in December.With the viewing area closed because of the coronavirus outbreak, fewer people than usual watched the lt off from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station.United Launch Alliance chief executive Tory Bruno said non-essential personnel were banned from the launch control room to reduce the size of the crowd.ldquoCanrsquot quite get ft everywhere. Surfaces will be cleaned between people, etc, tweeted Mr Bruno, who monitored the launch from company headquarters in Denver. title: josh-taylor-reveals-opponent-first-defence-world-titles
story: The Prestonpans super lightweight champion ndash who added the WBA belt to his IBF title by beating highly rated American Regis Prograis on points in the final of the World Boxing Super Series title: coronavirus-classes-queen-margaret-university-postponed-next-week
story: The university, near Musselburgh, outlined their stance yesterdayand vowed to keep students and staff updated of any future developments.Dr Richard Butt, deputy principal, said: "Queen Margaret University is continuing to monitor closely and follow healthcare and Government advice from Health Protection Scotland."Our campus and halls of residence remain open. We will comply with advice from Health Protection Scotland and the Scottish Government and take any necessary stepswe are advised to do so in the future."The guidance on the website will be updated,required, by pm each day."Learning and teaching will move entirely online by next Monday .Dr Butt added: "We will be moving to delivering teaching online."Reduced face-to-face teaching will begin from Monday , and no face-to face teaching will take place from March  until further notice."If there are any changes to your classes in the week beginning March , information will be published on the Hub."Academic staff will decide how best to conduct teaching and learning activities, using a range of resources to best support students."Meanwhile, all undergraduate and taught postgraduate exams and assessments scheduled for next Monday, including those for the Semester  exam period , and reassessments scheduled for the end of July, will be delivered online or by other methods of alternate assessment.Assessment type will be guided by academic discipline and academic staff expertise.Students will be notied as early as possible about what online assessments mean in practice.Inidual Learning Plan Adjustments will also continue.Students wishing tohome can do so.Dr Butt added: "We understand that some students, particularly those from overseas, may be anxious and you may be considering ing home."If you do decide tohome, you will not be penalised for doing so."Whilst we are changing our mode of learning and teaching and taking measures to be responsive to an evolving situation, QMUrsquos campus will remain open."We have had no indication from Health Protection Scotland or the Scottish Government that we should close, and buildings, services and facilities will run as usual.Staff and students can be on campus and our library, specialist facilities, student services, refectory, the halls of residences and Studentsrsquo Union are also open."We will continue to monitor and comply with advice from Health Protection Scotland and take any necessary steps, including possible campus closure,we are advised to do so in the future. "Graduation ceremonies scheduled for July will also be rescheduled, most likely to autumn.

title: coronavirus-musselburgh-racecourse-hold-meetings-behind-closed-doors
story: This weekrsquos Racing Post Go North race day will be open only to racing connections and will be in line with the Scottish Government recommendation that no events of more than  people should be held in light of the coronavirusoutbreak.Those attending will be asked to sign a self-declaration form that they do not have a temperature or symptoms associated with coronavirus. Anyone who has pre-booked tickets for either March race day will receive a full refund.Musselburgh Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth said: "Behind closed doors racing will comply with the guidelines set out by the Scottish Government and a meeting of less than  people, which includes participants, connections and staff, will not add any additional stress to emergency services."The racing industry, like many other sectors, is facing unprecedented challenges and is fighting for its future. We are keen to do whatever we can to support jobs and to mitigate loss of income, and holding meetings behind closed doors seems a sensible approach."Racingrsquos governing body the British Horseracing Authorityearlier announced all racing in Scotland, England and Wales would take place without spectators and with attendance limits until March .Nick Rust, chief executive of the BHA, said: "Racecourses and racing yards are embedded in their local communities and we are acutely aware of our responsibilities to protect public health."The restrictions we are putting in place to close racing to spectators and limit attendees will reduce demand on public services. We also have a range of measures in place designed in response to the Governmentrsquos guidance on public health and we will continue to update these as appropriate."Musselburgh will review how racing may proceed for its popular Betway Easter Saturday Race Day on April  as the situation develops and will continue to follow all Government and NHS advice on best practice on containing the virus.Regular updates on the racecourse website and social media channels,will advise racegoers, owners and trainers on any material changes to scheduled race meetings.For more information, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: council-petitioned-formally-adopt-masterplan-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: The plan, revealed in , outlines a potential future for the former Cockenzie Power Station site and was the result of a local authority consultation in  with communities and stakeholders surrounding the site.In the petition, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council claims that three years after the consultation, East Lothian Council ldquocontinue to go against the wishes and aspirations of our communities and stakeholders by not formally adopting the masterplan, causing ision, unrest and anger.It says that the councilrsquos ldquounwillingness to act has resulted in a number of plans and proposals, including Skyrorarsquos rocket engine testing facility and Inch Capersquos plan to build a substation, the latter having been approved.It adds: ldquoThe masterplan is our communitiesrsquo vision for the Cockenzie site ndash which includes our communitiesrsquo green space, pathways and parklands.ldquoThe masterplan brings leisure, recreation, tourism, industry and jobs whilst protecting our coastal environment and heritage site.The masterplan includes the creation of office and retail jobs as well as an ldquoenergy quarter, which would bring renewable energy jobs to the site.It also includes a ldquopublic art installation similar to the Kelpies in Falkirk, spaces for festivals, markets and other events, and retains the Battle of Prestonpans site.A community council spokesperson said: ldquoCockenzie and Port Seton Community Council call on East Lothian Councilto do the right thing and formally adopt the masterplan, which came about through guidance from the Scottish Parliament public petitions committee in .ldquoAt that time, East Lothian Council asked the communities bordering the Cockenzie site for their views on the future of the site through a series of workshops and consultation events for the communities and stakeholders.ldquoELC asked the communities answered the outcome is the ELC Peter Brett Cockenzie Masterplan.The Cockenzie Masterplan not only captures the communitiesrsquo vision, it has the potential for upwards of , jobs and also aligns with NPF goals.ldquoOur communities will continue to ask ELC to be as good as their word at the time of our participation in the masterplan consultations ndash to formally adopt the masterplan so that a template exists for the site which clearly reflects the hopes, dreams and aspirations of our communities. Where green space and environment are respected, enhanced and sit alongside industry and energy at Cockenzie, as has been the case for decades and generations.ldquoHad ELC formally adopted the masterplan, Inch Cape would not be located on the coastal frontage of the site, but in Zone , the Energy Quarter, and our communities would not have had the ision and angst caused by the Skyrora proposal to test rocket engines in the midst of communities.ldquoThis week, we read that a large area of land in the Scottish Borders has been passed to the community at a cost to them of pound so that their aspirations for the future can be achieved.ldquoWe ask that ELC either formally adopt the Cockenzie Masterplan or follow that lead and gt the site to the communities.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe recognise the importance of the sitersquos future and remain committed to working with and updating local stakeholders.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site has signicant potential for economic development and employment opportunities. The masterplan report ndash which reflects this and set out options for a mixed-use site ndash continues to be an important visionary document.ldquoSince its publication, Inch Cape Offshore Limitedhas received planning permission from Scottish Ministers to build onshore transmission works on part of the site.ldquoAlso, the National Planning Framework continues to include Cockenzie as a site of signicance for thermal energy generation.ldquoIt remains the case that we need to understand whether there are any implications for the site arising from the next National Planning Framework, as well as from potential future planning policy considerations and further technical work.ldquoWe see the masterplan report as one of a number of important considerations that will inform the councilrsquos input to the development plan process. The council is also determined that further technical work was required on the viability of port-related development.ldquoUnderstanding the full implications of all of this is key before the future of the whole site can be determined.The plan was originally drawn up by Peter Brett Associates, appointed by East Lothian Council.The petition can be viewed at change.org p east-lothian-council-petitioning-east-lothian-council-to-formally-adopt-the-cockenzie-masterplan

title: coronavirus-changes-waste-recycling-collections-announced
story: This is due to staff shortages as a result of the coronavirus outbreak.Green and blue recycling boxes will still be emptied on their usual day but, rather than both being emptied at the same time, the green box will be emptied on the first fortnight and the blue box the second fortnight.There will be no more brown bin collections as these have been suspended until further notice.Food waste and green bins for non-recyclable waste will still be collected as usual but the council urge that containers are placed out on the morning of collection by am.Where staffing allows, the council will try and honour any special uplt collections that have been booked.If items have not been collected by pm on the booked day, take them off the kerbside and contact the council to arrange an alternative date.Recycling centres are still open as normal and limits on vans and trailers remain in place however, some centres may close at short notice.

title: coronavirus-loans-offered-help-east-lothian-businesses-survive
story: Loan lsquoholidaysrsquo are also available on request for companies with an existing ELI Ltd loan.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Council Provost and member of the Board of Directors of ELI, said: ldquoI am sure financial support of any kind to businesses will be welcome at this time of great uncertainty, so Irsquom delighted that ELI can offer this."It is a worrying time for businesses of all sizes so itrsquos important that they get as much support as possible to weather the crisis and come out and flourish at the other side."I would encourage any eligible East Lothian businesses to take advantage of this as soon as possible.ldquoEast Lothian Council and ELI has a great record of local business support, including our highly successful East Lothian Gtcard Scheme and Business Gateway service."During this time, I would encourage businesses and iniduals to keep an eye on the dedicated webpage eastlothian.gov.uk coronavirus which will be regularly updated and contains advice on East Lothian Council services affected by Covid-, plus useful links to other organisations, including other sources of business and inidual financial support.ELI is a not-for-profit organisation which sits at armrsquosto East Lothian Council. The fund is managed by employees of the council but governed by a board of directors. The board comprises two East Lothian councillors and three private sector business people who provide their time free of charge to the company. It is authorised and regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority .Loans are available up to pound,, interest free with a holiday repayment period of four months. There is a five per cent arrangement fee to be paid up front and the loan will have a term of  months after the holiday period has ended. It is open to existing businesses only that have been trading for more than two years and have employees.Decisions on loans will be made within seven days and with funds can be paid within  hours.All applications and paperwork will be done via email and arrangement fee and loan award will be paid by bank transfer.

title: coronavirus-enjoyleisure-close-county-sports-facilities
story: In a statement yesterdayevening , BillAxon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, said: "To slow the spread of Covid-,the general public are being advised to stay at home as much as possible and avoid unnecessary social contact."The health and safety of our visitors and staff is our number one priority."We have taken the extremely dficult decision to close our facilities to the public temporarily and will continually monitor the advice from government so that we are in a good position to re-open as quickly as possible when appropriate."We would like to take this opportunity to thank our customers for their continued loyalty and support, and give special mention to our team of incredible colleagues and their continued dedication and commitment to the delivery of enjoyleisure services.From close of business on Friday,enjoyleisure will closeits sports centres and swimming pools, pitches andpavilions, MeadowmillAthletics Arena andits climbing wall at Tranent.Enjoyleisure-managed golf coursesMusselburgh Old Linksand Winterfield, Dunbar, will remain open to the public for now.All fitness and swimming lesson membership customers will have their monthly direct debit payments reduced to poundper month to cover bank and administration costs.Whileall childrenrsquos and adultscoached activity programmes -including gymnastics, trampolining, climbing, and swimming lessons - will cease tomorrow.All upcoming events, hosted by enjoyleisure or other external organisations at enjoyleisure facilities,have been cancelled or postponed.

title: coronavirus-scottish-seabird-centre-closed
story: The closure came into effect yesterdayand it is not known how long it will last.In a statement, Susan Davies, chief executive of the Seabird Centre, said: ldquoIn view of the latest Scottish Government and Public Health Scotland advice, it is with regret that we have to advise our members and visitors that the Scottish Seabird Centre is closing its doors for the time-being."The safety and wellbeing of our staff, volunteers and visitors is of paramount importance to us at this time.ldquoWe are immensely grateful for all the kind words and offers of support we have received since reopening our newly refreshed Discovery Experience and Learning Hub last year.ldquoMany visitors who have dropped in over the last few days have also told us just how much they also enjoy coming into the centre to socialise. We are sorry that we cannot continue to offer our services just now.ldquoYour continued support has meant a lot to our dedicated frontline staff team, at this uncertain time, and importantly has helped support the conservation and education work that charity delivers.ldquoDuring the closure of our visitor centre, our dedicated team will continue to work behind the scenes on project resources, new interactives and to offer new digital resources for members and participants in our activities and events.ldquoWe will keep you up to date with these as they become available via our social media channels. We are also exploring options for appropriate outdoor activities and flexible use of our cafeacute and gt shop whilst closed.ldquoIf you have any queries please do get in touch via info@seabird.org or by calling the office   and leaving a voice message. One of the team will get back to you, although it may take a little longer than usual.ldquoWe will continue to closely monitor the official advice and will keep you updated on our position through our social media channels and website.ldquoWe hope to be able to welcome you back in the near future. In the meantime please stay safe and well.Some of the countyrsquos other big attractions, including several museums and historic castles, announced their closures earlier this week.

title: coronavirus-schools-across-east-lothian-now-closed
story: East LothianCouncil says it is opening a number of childrenrsquos hubs in each of its school cluster areas for youngsters whose parents are identied as key workers or who are vulnerable.The local authority intends to use digital technology to continue lessons for youngsters who were sent home with packs of school work, including books and usernames and passwords to access Google classrooms.A youth football club is also opening its clubhouse for young people who cannot access the internet to connect free for homework.Preston Athletic YFC, based in Prestonpans, have invited children along between pm and pm during the week, with food and drink also being supplied to the youngsters.The club said: ldquoAs of Monday, March , we will open the clubhouse Monday to Friday,  pm. We welcome children who do not have internet access at home to come along and use our internet free off charge to do homework they must bring their own tablet or laptop.ldquoWe will give all children a free juice and biscuit, adults can have a free hot drink. Children can also havea kick about on the Gthey wish.One of the clubrsquos coaches has offered to produce soup and sandwiches for children who attend and Sugar Rush Creations has offered to provide all youngsters who are doing homework in the clubhouse with free popcorn.Meanwhile, East Lothian Council has announced it will have childrenrsquos hubs at the following schools: Dunbar Primary School St Maryrsquos Primary School Haddington Primary School Law Primary School, North BerwickPreston Tower Primary School , PrestonpansSandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, Tranentand Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, Musselburgh.The hubs are expected to be available to children who have at least one parent identied as a key worker and no other adult at home, and will also oversee the distribution of free school meals to eligible children and continue providing support for learning to children with additional support needs.The councilrsquos chief operating officer for education Lesley Brown said:ldquoThis is an extremely challenging time for our school communities, including parents, carers, children and staff. Irsquod like to thank everyone for the support you have given our teams in recent days.ldquoClearly the unprecedented decision to close all schools in Scotland by close of play todaypresents major logistical dficulties and inconvenience for families. Wersquore grateful to everyone for your patience and understanding as we respond to this situation.ldquoWe have continued to work on arrangements which we intend to implement in the coming week. More details will be made available as soon as practically possible.ldquoThanks to our teachers, supported by other staff, we are carrying out work to prepare online learning opportunities to maintain teaching as far as possible. Schools are in touch with parents and carers about this.ldquoWe will be working with our private and voluntary nurseries and our out of school care partners to provide a holistic package of support and will be in touch with them very soon.

title: coronavirus-churches-urged-stop-services-prevent-spread-virus
story: A spokesperson for the Church of Scotland said on Tuesday: ldquoThe Scottish Governmentnow advisesthat people should minimise social contact by avoiding crowded areas and large gatherings, including religious congregations, and smaller gatherings.ldquoThe Church of Scotland now asks, in the strongest terms, that all gatherings for worship should cease until further notice.ldquoOther Scottish churches are taking similar actions."This obviously includes Easter services. Some Presbyteries have already instructed this action. This will include, but not be restricted to: housegroups, meetings for youth work, and church cafes.ldquoIt will still be possible for an inidual to offer a livestream of a sermon and prayers.ldquoChurch buildings can be kept open as a place for people to come and pray.Notices should be clearly displayedasking that visitors observe robust hand hygiene, including washing their hands on entry to the church.On weddings and funerals, the Church said that ldquosensitive conversations will need to take place between those affected.The Rev Alison McDonald, from St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Haddington, sent a message to her congregation after the Church of Scotland called for services to be cancelled.She said weekly readings, prayers and reflections would be posted online and plans are being consideredto open the church building for ldquopersonal prayer as the coronavirus crisis continues.The Scottish Episcopal Churchhas also asked its clergy to cease church services.The Most Rev Dr Mark Strange, Primus of the SEC, said: ldquoThis is a dficult time for many people some are fearful for themselves or their relatives, while others want to know how to help stem the spread of the virus.ldquoOur guidance is given not just to address medical concerns but also with pastoral concern being uppermost in our hearts and minds, particularly the care of the vulnerable in our congregations and communities.Church buildings will be allowed to stay open for private prayer. The church will also deliver a video service of the Eucharist every Sunday through its website for those wanting to worship at home.The Catholic Church has cancelled public Masses across Scotland from Thursday and they will not take place until further notice.Masses will still be said in private in churches but not in front of parishioners live streaming will be in place and available where possible.Catholic churches themselves will not be closed completely to allow time for private prayer.

title: weightlifting-headteacher-earns-podium-position-international-event
story: Lynda Banks represented Great Britain at the European Masters Classic Powerlting Championships in France last Monday .The Cockenzie Primary School headteacher lted a whopping  kilogrammes across the three events in the age -,  kilogrammes category, to come home with two bronze medals from the competition in Albi, near Toulouse.Ms Banksrsquo powerlting prowess came about ldquoby pure chance.She had started training at a gym in Inverness when she was , with a view to being strong enough to complete a chin-up.That was successfully achieved and a love of deadlting followed, with the -year-oldrsquos first competition in Dumfries in .Within  months, she had a gold medal for deadlts as part of the British team.Ms Banks swapped Hilton Primary School in Inverness for East Lothian in October last year, the new head replacing Jacqui MacKinnon, who moved on to North Berwickrsquos Law Primary School.The headteacherrsquos positive mental attitude influences her approach to school leadership, and she has shared with schoolchildren in assembly her experiences competing.The Edinburgh resident said: ldquoOne of our school values is positivity.ldquoWhen I competed at the World Championships in Texas I pulled kg, which I hadnrsquot done before, and took overall third place in the world.ldquoHaving a positive attitude is so important.ldquoWe work to foster a sense of school achievement, with a wall where pupils and staff are encouraged to share a wide range of their achievements such as chanter, ing, rock climbing, so we can all celebrate them.The children also enjoy seeing her collection of medals, which she keeps in her office.Five days after making the move to Cockenzie Primary School and nursery, which is home to  pupils, Ms Banks was competing in the British Championships, retaining her title in her age and weight category for the fth successive year, and achieving three personal bests: squat .kg, bench press .kg and total kg, having deadlted kg, too.It was this performance that led to an invitation to take part in Team GB in Albi.The headteacher primarily trains in Edinburgh, although she has started attending Meadowmill Sports Centre, to help fit her training around her busy school schedule.She also works with a nutritionist and said: ldquoI want to be as strong as I can to compete and stay at a healthy weight.ldquoI eat healthily ndash I eat a lot of chicken, rice and porridge and drink plenty of water.ldquoHowever, I can still have cakeI want to!

title: tims-tales-monkey-delivery
story: ldquoWRITE something uplting or funny, my we Kate told me this morning. Shersquos right, of course. We need such stories just now.My response was: ldquoYes, we all need to make our own version of Stone Soup.My youngest daughter overheard me. ldquoYuck, I donrsquot want that, I want porridge for breakfast like usual, she said.I reassured her and reminded her of the story. Itrsquos an old tale Irsquove shared in these pages before. It has many versions and I base the story in a land when there is a famine and people have very little food on which to survive, and so understandably people keep what little they have for their own use.But then a wise traveller fills his pot with water and begins to boil it over a fire. Then he adds a stone. People get curious and ask: ldquoWhat are you making  The traveller replies: ldquoStone soup.ldquoStone soup  Never heard of that.ldquoOh, itrsquos delicious and very filling.ldquoCould I try some ldquoOf course, but it would taste betteryou had something to add to it, says the traveller.And so as the story unfolds, each person adds a little to the pot, which means in the end the soup really is delicious and filling, and there is enough for all, because everyone has shared the little they have.But before they eat, the traveller does one last thing ndash takes out the stone!My daughter remembered the story and was reassured stone soup wasnrsquot on the breakfast menu. But I think the storyrsquos meaning has deeper signicance than just the sharing of food. Itrsquos also about the sharing of ourselves, and how adding a little bit of who we are can transform the pot of community.In the midst of all the fear and panic around us just now, this is what is happening. People are helping out, checking on neighbours and thinking how their own behaviour can affect others who are more vulnerable.And in all this, our mental wellbeing is as important as our physical health. Irsquom reminded of something my motherrsquos partner once told me. His name was Harry. He was originally from Holland and in his childhood he lived through the horric Dutch famine of -.He said: ldquoWe survived on rotten potato soup, tulip bulbs and a joke a day. Sometimes the jokes were as rotten as the potatoes but just as important!We need to smile, laugh and feel connected, especially in dficult times. We can all begin our own metaphorical stone soup and invite others to contribute and share.For example, many of my fellow storytellers are arranging online storytelling sessions. I will be telling stories online for the schools I currently work with and Irsquom happy to do likewise for any other organisation or group ndash once my six-year-old has taught me how the technology works!There are local musicians playing online gigs, people sharing recipes, visiting older family members outside their windows, writing letters and telephoning people for a chat the list goes on. One idea can lead to another, and soon a new community pot is made!Every contribution, no matter how seemingly small, can make a big dference to that pot. And in so doing, it will challenge that sense of despair and powerlessness that so many of us feel right now.So the question should be: Whatrsquos your thing  How can you safely share it  Whatrsquos your amusing or uplting story or your talent  Think about it and letrsquos share, for others, as well as ourselves.And so in the spirit of this, here is my wee contribution for this week itrsquos a funny wee tale passed onto me, so I claim no credit or originality for it. It was told to me by an Irish friend, but Irsquove adapted it slightly.There was this van driver called George who got a job delivering monkeys to the zoo. Unfortunately, his van broke down and while waiting for the mechanic the monkeys began to get restless.Then another van driver called Archie pulled up and askedhe could help.ldquoIrsquom late for my delivery. If I give you pound, will you take these monkeys to the zoo  asked George.ldquoSure, said Archie.So Archie took the monkeys away in his van.George waited for the mechanic and finally his van was repaired. He then set off for the zoo to make sure the monkeys were delivered successfully.But to his surprise, he saw Archie walking along the street with the monkeys!George called out to him: ldquoWhat are you doing  I gave you pound to take the monkeys to the zoo!Archie called back: ldquoI did, but we got a group discount, I have some money left, so now Irsquom taking them to the cinema!

title: coronavirus-residents-urged-keep-helping-east-lothian-foodbank
story: The foodbank, based in Tranent, provides food parcels to vulnerable members of the community.Candace Higgins, foodbank director, said the situation was changing ldquohour by hour, adding: ldquoWe are still operating as normal but certain protocols have been put in place when delivering food parcels.Volunteers making deliveries are now simply knocking on doors or ringing bells, rather than waiting for doors to be opened to them. The parcels can then be left in safe places, while, at the charityrsquos headquarters on Civic Square, ldquostringent cleanliness and health and safety rules are in place.Candace praised the local community for their continued support in making donations to the group.She said: ldquoWe are really benefiting from having such a fantastic community. Donations have gone up rather than down.However, she also issued a call for people to stop panic or bulk buying.She added: ldquoWe are running low on chopped tomatoes, long-le fruit juice, instant mash potato and tinned potatoes. In terms of household items, it would be the same things as everyone  is running low on ndash kitchen roll, toilet roll and baby wipes.The foodbank is staffed by volunteers and Candace said they anticipated a number of volunteers who are over the age of  would have to remain in their homes over the coming weeks, with a reduced schedule of deliveries. Instead, moves could be made to change the model to a pantry and larder model.The foodbank was visited at the end of last week by the countyrsquos MP, Kenny MacAskill, who met with  volunteers.He said: ldquoThe foodbank is a treasure, but the circumstances that have made these projects so important are the result of bad choices by successive Governments.ldquoItrsquos especially important now with the coronavirus pandemic that we continue to support our local foodbank to make sure those in crisis are able to have at least the comfort of a hot meal.

title: first-minister-must-act-now-slow-spread-virus
story: Speaking in a televised address from Bute House in Edinburgh, the First Minister warned the number of Covid- cases is ldquoset to rise sharply.She said everyone must act now to slow the spread of the virus, adding that we must also reduce the number of people we meet and come into contact with.The new advice was given after discussions with scientists and chief medical officer Dr Catherine Calderwood.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoI know how dficult this is. But it is vital to reduce our risk of getting the virus.ldquoAnd to reduce the risk of infecting those who are most vulnerable of becoming seriously ill or dying. In short, it will save lives.ldquoIt also gives our NHS the best chance of coping. Wersquove put the NHS on an emergency footing. Wersquore taking steps to increase the capacity of our hospitals and intensive care wards.ldquoBut those who work in our health and social care services will be tested like never before.ldquoMost of us have friends and family working in the NHS ndash my own sister and sister-in-law are among them. The debt of gratitude we owe all of them is enormous.ldquoThe Scottish Government will do all we can to support you.ldquoAs government, we are asking you to take unprecedented steps. So the level of support we provide to you must be unprecedented in .During her address the First Minister spoke specically to both ends of the population in a bid to convey how to continue le as the country is ldquoentering stormy waters.She said: ldquoTo older people ndash we are asking you to stay away from your grandkids, from the people you love.ldquoThatrsquos hard. But it is for your protection, so you can stay around to see them grow up.ldquoTo children ndash I know this is a strange time. Yoursquore away from school, and wonrsquot be able to spend as much time with friends.ldquoThe adults around you are probably feeling a bit anxious too. So help them. Follow their advice. Study and do your homework. But donrsquot forget to have fun. And wash your hands.ldquoModern technology is sometimes a curse, it can now be a leline.ldquoPhone or Skype loved ones. Text neighbours or drop a note through their door to seethey need help. Maybe even write a letter to your grandparents.Ms Sturgeon also told people to support their local businesses where possible, ldquobut please, do not panic buy.Earlier on Friday she had suggested Scots could face ldquoeven stricter and more dficult measures to help curb the spread.Dr Calderwood also said there is ldquoevidence of sustained community transmission across Scotland.She warned: ldquoWe are on the cusp of a rapid acceleration of cases of coronavirus in Scotland.ldquoWe have seen increased numbers day on day in the past week or two, and we also have evidence of sustained community transmission across Scotland.ldquoAll of the scientic advice tells us these measures will be effective to slow the spread of the virus, to prevent many people becoming so sick that they are admitted to hospital and sadly dying because of the disease.ldquoBut the measures will not be effectivepeople donrsquot comply with them.

title: explained-difference-self-isolating-social-distancing
story: As spring begins the days are getting longer and warmer, and people are getting the urge to venture outside of their homes after winter.But amid the spread of coronavirus, many people are not sure whether it is safe for them to get out in the open air, or whether they have to stay inside.Here is the dference between social distancing, and social isolating - and what it means for you.Who needs to self isolate The governmentrsquos advice is that anyone who is experiencing symptoms of coronavirus - a dry cough, fever, or dficulty breathing - must self-isolate for a two week period.Anyone classied as lsquovulnerablersquo also has to self-isolate. This includes people over , as well as people with underlying conditions that could make the symptoms of coronavirus worse.Unfortunately for these people, self-isolation means not leaving your house - making going walks outside or meeting friends an impossibility. But the government does say people who are self-isolating can keep windows open to get fresh air.Whatrsquos social distancing The government is advising everyone who is not currently self-isolating to still practise social distancing.This means not meeting with friends and family, staying away from crowded areas, avoiding all non-essential travel, and working from home where possible.Luckily for these people, there is no restriction on going for walks outside. The government website actually encourages people to get plenty of exercise and fresh air.ldquoAt times like these, the website reads, ldquoit can be easy to fall into unhealthy patterns of behaviour which in turn can make you feel worse."Its only warning is not to get too close to other people when outside, asking walkers to stay at least two metres away from each other.Coronavirus: the facts by the World Health Organisation and the NHSWhat is coronavirus COVID- is a respiratory illness that can affect lungs and airways. It is caused by a virus called coronavirus.What caused coronavirus The outbreak started in Wuhan in China in December  and it is thought that the virus, like others of its kind, has come from animals.How is it spread As this is such a new illness, experts still arenrsquot sure how it is spread. But similar viruses are spread in cough droplets. Therefore covering your nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing, and disposing of used tissues straight away is advised. Viruses like coronavirus cannot live outside the body for very long.What are the symptoms The NHS states that the symptoms are: a dry cough, high temperature and shortness of breath - but these symptoms do not necessarily mean you have the illness. Look out for flu-like symptoms, such as aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose and a sore throat. Itrsquos important to remember that some people may become infected but wonrsquot develop any symptoms or feel unwell.What precautions can be taken Washing your hands with soap and water thoroughly. The NHS also advises to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleevewhen you cough or sneeze put used tissues in the bin immediately and try to avoid close contact with people who are unwell. Also avoiding touching eyes, nose and mouth unless your hands are clean.Government adviceAs of Monday, March , the government advised that everyone should be observing social distancing - avoiding unnecessary travel and working from home where possible. Anyone with a cough or cold symptoms now needs to self-isolate with their entire household for  days.The over s or anyone who is vulnerable or living with an underlying illness are being asked to be extra careful and stay at home to self-isolate.For more information on government advice, please check their website.Should I avoid public places The advice now is to avoid public places and any non-essential travel. Travel abroad is also being advised against for the next  days at least, and many European countries have closed their borders.What should I doI feel unwell Donrsquot go to your GP but instead call NHS  or look online at the coronavirus service that can tell youyou need medical help and what to do next.When to call NHS NHS  should be usedyou feel unwell with coronavirus symptoms, have been in a country with a high risk of coronavirus in the last  days oryou have been in close contact with someone with the virus.

title: tesco-take-20-000-new-staff
story: Tesco has become the latest supermarket to announce plans to recruit new staff to cope with the coronavirus outbreak overwhelming stores.The UKrsquos biggest grocer said it will recruit , temporary workers for at least the next  weeks.Its recruitment drive was launched on Wednesday, adding ldquosince then we have already been overwhelmed by support from the public and thank everyone who has applied to work with us in stores.Some staff are being interviewed, processed and working within the same day, Tesco added.Tescorsquos HR chief, Natasha Adams, said: ldquoIrsquom so proud to be welcoming thousands of new colleagues to Tesco. Thank you to everyone offering to help as we work day and night to keep our shelves full for customers. The community spirit at Tesco is fantastic and together, we can do this.The decision was made as Asda, Aldi and Lidl all announced new jobs on Friday, which followed similar moves by Morrisonrsquos and Co-op earlier in the week.Supermarkets across the country have been struggling with overwhelming demand, and are expected to see an increase in shoppers over the weekend after the Governmentrsquos decree to shut down all restaurants and bars.

title: coronavirus-dunbar-civic-week-postponed
story: Dunbarrsquos Civic Week was due to take place from June  to  but the townrsquos community councillors have taken the tough decision to cancel the annual celebration amid fears surrounding coronavirus.George Robertson, chairman of the Civic Week planning committee, spoke to the Courier on Thursday, with the decision officially taken to cancel the event just days later.He said: ldquoThere are discussions taking place and it is very likely to be cancelled.ldquoThat is my recommendation to the community council and I am awaiting them to come back to me.Traditionally, Civic Week, which started in , features dozens of events, ranging from football tournaments to a cycle ride.The townrsquos leboat station opens its doors to visitors and live music is performed at The Battery, at the townrsquos harbour.Central to the event is the crowning of Dunbarrsquos Civic Week Queen, who is a randomly chosen female P pupil from the town.Mr Robertson said there were concerns that coronavirus would decimate the programme, which is already in the process of being drawn up.He said: ldquoYou cannot have a fun day or a parade with  people.ldquoA lot of people are going to be in lockdown.ldquoIt is a real blow and it could not have come at a worse time [the event was due to celebrate  years] but in the grand scheme of things, cancelling Dunbar Civic Week, like Wimbledon and Glastonbury, does not amount to a whole lot of grievance.ldquoI was quite anxious we made a decision.ldquoWe were discussing this before the school closure came about and we were due to have a draw on March  for the Royal Court.Mr Robertson, who is also a member of the townrsquos community council, said ldquoa lot of preparation had already gone into the event and thanked the work of volunteers Eileen Moore and Sanchita Patjoshi in pulling everything together.It remains to be seenthe event will be rescheduled for later in the year or simply resume in the summer of .Mr Robertson noted that attempting to hold the event later in the year created a number of other potential issues.No one knows when everyday events couldto normal in the wake of COVID-, while the children who are currently in P would have moved on to Dunbar Grammar School by the time the event could be held.This yearrsquos event was also due to mark the th anniversary of the granting of the Royal Charter to Dunbar.The Royal Charter was granted to Dunbar by King David the Secondin .This came about because Berwick-upon-Tweed was then in English hands and the lucrative revenues from the export of border wool was lost to the Scottish crown.The granting of a Royal Charter to Dunbar meant that this trade could now go via Dunbar and the port of Belhaven, and revenues revert to Scotland.The th anniversary was celebrated in grand style in  with the very first Dunbar Civic Week, and Civic Week has continued annually ever since.

title: alex-salmond-cleared-east-lothian-mp-says-resignations-required
story: Mr Salmond was on trial on  charges, which included charges of attempted rape and sexual assault.The jury retired to deliberate its verdict on Friday afternoon after a two-week trial but came to its decision today.The -year-old was found not guilty of  charges and not proven for another.In a post on Twitter, East Lothians MP Kenny MacAskill, a known ally of Mr Salmond, said he was ldquodelighted for the former First Minister, adding: ldquoSome resignations now required".

title: coronavirus-scotland-essentially-already-lockdown-businesses-told-close
story: Nicola Sturgeon also indicated that Scotland is essentiallyalready in ldquolockdown, but without it being enforced.She warned that people should remain at home ldquounless itrsquos absolutely essential to go out ndash while Scotlandrsquos chief medical officer, Catherine Calderwood, said that people can go out and exercise once a day but ldquoonly in small family groups.Ms Sturgeon said that the advice issued is ldquorules that we are expecting people to comply with and that businesses that cannot operate remotely should ldquoconsider closing or hibernating.She added: ldquoFor everyone, you must stay at home unless it is absolutely essential to go out. That includes working from home wherever possible.ldquoStay away from crowded places, even out of doors. When there are other people around, stay two metres distance from them.ldquoThat advice is for everyone but it is especially vitalyou are over , eligible for the flu vaccine or pregnant. At all times, follow the advice on washing your hands, using tissues and touching your face.Ms Sturgeon pleaded with businesses that have not yet closed their doors to the public.She said: ldquoIf you are not providing essential items like food and medicines, then please also close now.ldquoThere are still too many people across our country who are being expected to or are expecting to go to work as normal. That presents a serious and unnecessary risk of spreading the virus.Ms Sturgeon added that building sites and hair salons should also close to help in the efforts to suppress the coronavirus pandemic.She added: ldquoI know this is a dficult situation for businesses and I know dficult judgements are having to be made.ldquoI have therefore asked for additional guidance to be drawn up urgently by government for businesses that will make clear exactly what we are expecting of them and how they can make theright judgements on what is essential and whatis not essential.ldquoWe are pushing for and are very hopeful of seeing very seen, further measures to support freelancers, the self-employed and contract workers.ldquoIt should enable businesses to do the right thing for themselves and for their workers.Dr Calderwood said that it was important that people couldleeavetheir homes to exercise once a day for mental and physical wellbeing, but urged people to do it in small family groups to stop the spread of coronavirus.She said: ldquoPeople should go out once a day to exercise but donrsquot do it except in small family groups.ldquoWe are going to have to adapt to le in this new world. We are really in this for the marathon, not a sprint.The First Minister also indicated that Scotland and wider UK is essentially already in ldquolockdown as has been described in Italy and other countries ndash albeit without the enforcement.She said: ldquoIt is very possible that in the days to come, we will see more stringent measures be applied.ldquoIf we take a step back from the word lsquolockdownrsquo, and think about what all the components of that would be - asking people to stay at home and not go to work unless it isvitally essential, asking people not to go shopping unless itrsquos for food and medicine, asking people to keep their distance, not gather in crowds of people.ldquoThatrsquos essentially the elements of what you are seeing in other countries where it has been described as lockdown."I guess the missing bit that we may have to move tothe advice tells us itrsquos necessary, iswhether that is beingissued in a way of advice, although Irsquom being very clear we want people to treat it as rules, or whether there is more enforcement on that. I canrsquot rule that out.She added: ldquoAs First Minister, I will not hesitate to do what is necessary here. Irsquom not ruling anything out.ldquoWhat Irsquom being crystal clear on is that the public donrsquot have to wait for lockdowns or enforcement to do the right things.ldquoItrsquos within the ability of each and every one of us as citizens to do the right things now. Donrsquot wait for somebody to tell you - please do it.

title: coronavirus-east-lothians-coastal-car-parks-closed
story: Childrens play areas in the county have also been closed.East Lothian Council said the decision, which takes effect immediately,was taken due to "the escalating challenges posed by the coronavirus outbreak, the need to ensure appropriate social distancing between iniduals and to reduce the risk of cross-infection from contact surfaces".Monica Patterson, chief executive of East Lothian Council, said: ldquoFrom the outset of the coronavirus outbreak, we have been clear about the need to follow national health and government advice.ldquoAlthough we appreciate that the coastal car parks are popular with those who enjoy our fantastic local beaches ndash particularly during good weather ndash there are concerns about this presenting dficulty for people following social distancing advice at busy times."Itrsquos essential that people avoid gatherings at this time and keep two metres away from other people."Advice against non-essential travel is also in place.ldquoDue to the risk of cross-infection from contact surfaces, we have also reluctantly made the decision to temporarily close the councilrsquos childrenrsquos play areas. This relates specically to areas with play equipment rather than larger parks open spaces which have play areas within them.ldquoWhile we appreciate people will be disappointed, we believe these decisions are in the best interests of everyonersquos health and wellbeing as we respond to the unprecedented challenges presented by this outbreak.The closurealso appliesto the toilet and showering facilities at the car parks.The council is also urging people not to travel to access open space and coastal areas outwith the town or village they reside in, as this could speed up the spread of the virus area to area.The council stated: "Social distancing is key. Everyone should avoid congregating in large groups and stay at least two metres apart from others at all times."We would urge young people and their parents carers to be conscious of this."We would also remind residents that enjoyleisure facilities throughout East Lothian are currently closed ndash from today this will include all G pitches that are fenced off."Images of packed car parks with jowl at ice-cream shops.The Governments current advice during the coronaviruscrisis is to practise "social distancing", which involves keeping a distance of at least two metres from anyone other than those you live with.However, going for walks and exercising is still allowed as long as the two-metre distance from others is kept.The footage of the packed car parks and shops led to two councillors title: coronavirus-council-introduces-emergency-recess-procedures
story: The decision was made by the chief executive following consultation with the three political group leaderson the council.The decision means:All business undertaken during the emergency recess will be subject to reports to East Lothian Councilrsquos Membersrsquo Library, and a summary report will be presented to the next council meeting outlining all business undertaken.Chief executive Monica Patterson said: ldquoIn the view of the increasingly dficult situation arising from the coronavirus outbreak, after consultation with political group leaders, I have made the decision to invoke the COVID- emergency recess procedures.ldquoThe outbreak is presenting signicant and developing challenges to the delivery of public services.ldquoIt is essential that the councilrsquos focus is on continuing to take actions to sustain critical services as far possible, maximising the availability of our resources in as flexible a manner as possible.ldquoMore generally, we continue to follow national guidelines while implementing appropriate measures.ldquoIt is important that we continue to support each other and the communities we serve at this very dficult time.

title: coronavirus-new-changes-recycling-collections-recycling-centres-closed
story: Collection of both the green and blue recycling boxes will resume across East Lothian on each households normal calendar dates.That follows a previous change brought in on Monday which had seen green and blue recycling boxes still emptied on their usual day but, rather than both being emptied at the same time, the green box emptied on the first fortnight and the blue box the second fortnight.Now, both will be emptied together again.The council is also continuing to collect non-recyclable waste fortnightly, as per each households calendars.Brown bins for garden waste collections remain suspended until further notice, as had taken effect from Monday.A council spokesperson said: "If this situation changes due to staff shortages during the current coronavirus crisis, we will issue further updates via our website and social media. Please keep an eye out for these."Meanwhile, all four of the countys recycling centres are closed until further notice."We will update you as soon as that situation changes," the spokesperson added.

title: coronavirus-public-toilets-east-lothian-closed

title: wetherspoons-boss-tells-staff-go-work-tesco-leaving-no-pay
story: After being forced to closehundred of pubs over the weekend to battle the spread of Covid-, Martin sent a video to staff members claiming that he would be relying on a Government grant to pay workers.However, the grant will not be available for well over a monthand Martin,who is reportedly worth over pound million, will not be covering staff wages until then.More than , workers have been left without a future pay date, unsure how they will be able to afford rent, bills or groceries.A letter from members of Wetherspoons staffOther companies, such as Costa Coffee, have guaranteed that staff will be paid for the next eight weeks despite also shutting their doors.The move came shortly after Martin claimed the global pandemic was nothing more than a "health scare" and that the closing pubs would be an "over the top" reaction.In the video sent to staff, in which Martin appears holding a mug, he stated that the need to close "puts everyone in a terrible position"."And I know youre all sitting there wondering what the hell is happening and over the weekend I had lots of phone calls with dferent people and were trying to sort it out as best we can in this highly unusual situation."The Wetherspoons bossthen encourages staff to go work at Tesco.He said: "I know that all our trade now has gone to supermarkets. Not only our trade, but the trade from cafeacutes, leisure centres, restaurants etc."So we have had lots of calls from supermarkets, Tesco alone want , people to join them. Thats half the amount of people who work in our pubs."Martin then says staff member have the option to leave rather than waiting for payments to begin - but theres no guarantee they would get their job back at a future date.He said: "If Im honest, I could say you can get the furlough payments and stay at home."If youre offered a job at a supermarket, many of you will want to do that. story: At the beginning of next month, the limit will change from pound to pound.Why is the change happening The move has been name to helpreduce physical contact with keypads on chip and pin machines due to the coronavirus crisis.It is hoped the increased limit will helpin the fight against Covid-.When will the change take place The British Retail Consortiumsaid the move would begin on April , , but warned that implementation in some shops may take longer.What has the British Retail Consortium said about this BRC head of payments policyAndrew Cregansaid: ldquoThe last contactless limit increase to pound took two years to implement but, given the extraordinary circumstances we face today, this new pound limit will be rolled-out from next week.ldquoSome shops will take longer to make the necessary changes, given the strain theyrsquore under. In the meantime, most customers can continue to make contactless payments for higher amounts using their smart phone.Coronavirus: the facts from the World Health Organisation and the NHSCOVID- is a respiratory illness that can affect lungs and airways. It is caused by a virus called coronavirus.The outbreak started in Wuhan in China in December  and it is thought that the virus, like others of its kind, has come from animals.As this is such a new illness, experts still arenrsquot sure how it is spread. But, similar viruses are spread in cough droplets. Therefore, covering your nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing, and disposing of used tissues straight away is advised. Viruses like coronavirus cannot live outside the body for very long.The NHS states that the symptoms are: a dry cough, high temperature and shortness of breath - but these symptoms do not necessarily mean you have the illness. Look out for flu-like symptoms, such as aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose and a sore throat. Itrsquos important to remember that some people may become infected but wonrsquot develop any symptoms or feel unwell.Washing your hands with soap and water thoroughly. The NHS also advises to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleevewhen you cough or sneeze put used tissues in the bin immediately and try to avoid close contact with people who are unwell. Also avoiding touching eyes, nose and mouth unless your hands are clean.As of Monday,March , the prime minister has put the UK into lockdown and instructed all citizens to stay at home. People can only leave their homes to exercise once a day, go shopping for food and medication, travel for medical needs or to care for a vulnerable person, and travel to work onlyessential. Police will be able to enforce these restrictions.All non-essential shops will close with immediate effect, as will playgrounds, places of worship and libraries. Large events or gatherings of more than two people cannot go ahead, including weddings and celebrations. Funerals can only be attended by immediate family. Children of separated parents can go between both parents homes.Anyone with a cough or cold symptoms needs to self-isolate with their entire household for  days.The Government has now instructed bars, restaurants, theatres and non-essential businesses to close and will review on a lsquomonth to monthrsquo basis. Schools closed from Friday, March , for the foreseeable future, and exams have been cancelled.The over-s or anyone who is vulnerable or living with an underlying illness are being asked to be extra careful and stay at home to self-isolate. People with serious underlying health conditions will be contacted and strongly advised to undertake "shielding" for  weeks.For more information on Government advice, please check their website.You should now avoid public places and any non-essential travel. Travel abroad is also being advised against for the next  days at least, and many European countries have closed their borders.Donrsquot go to your GP but instead call NHS  or look online at the coronavirus service that can tell youyou need medical help and what to do next.NHS  should be usedyou feel unwell with coronavirus symptoms, have been in a country with a high risk of coronavirus in the last  days oryou have been in close contact with someone with the virus.

title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. title: TV REVIEW  Did Glasgow-set drama The Nest get off to a flying start
story: FORGET about the column inches Michelle Mone has racked up, or the seat in the House of Lords. Nothing says you have officially arrived more than a name check in a BBC Sunday night drama.ldquoIrsquom going to be an entrepreneur, says the troubled teenager at the heart of The Nest. ldquoKnow that lassie that invented that bra  Michelle Mone  Now shersquos a baroness or some ****. business card. The Nest is set in Monersquos hometown of Glasgow. While ostensibly a drama about surrogacy, it is really a tale of two cities, two Scotlands, the haves and the have nots.Property developer Dan and his musician we Emily , have everything, including a stunning lochside home, but not the child they long for.Kayahas a flat in Possil with barely a stick of furniture in it, and the kind of temper that sees her threaten to stab her case worker with a bottle.The opposites collide when Emily gets lost one night and hits -year-old Kaya with her car. So far, so Bonfire of the Vanities. The teen starts to work her way into the older womanrsquos le and, long story short, offers to be a surrogate infor pound,.Dan thinks this is a crazy idea, not to mention illegal. As does his sister, his lawyer, Emilyrsquos colleague, and probably every viewer watching. Many a drama would struggle to get beyond such a point, but the writer here is Nicole Taylor , who carefully takes each objection and picks away at it.: Susan Swarbrick meets Martin CompstonUltimately, the viewer has to believe that Emily is unhinged by grief, and that Dan would give in because he is desperate to keep her. Madness happens when people convince themselves a situation is all or nothing, black or white. That is how noir works.Even so, Taylorrsquos story is such a high-wire act that it needs to keep propelling itself onwards at speed or it will crash to the ground in a heap of improbabilities.Helping immensely with the task of keeping the viewer on side is a terric cast. Rundle is a convincing mix of fierce determination and eggshell fragility. Mack, a real find, does that bravest of things as an actor and makes herself an unlikeable pain in the neck.Then there is Compston. Once the prince of Sunday nights as Essex wide boy DS Arnott in Line of Duty, he is even better back on his home turf and in his own accent.It was a nice touch by Taylor to make Dan a bad boy made good, eventhe working class middle class contrast was laid on a a bit thick. Every time Kaya appeared the score would slip into menacing music mode, as though people who do not live in beautul lochside homes were naturally best avoided.What a house, mind. As in Guilt, Glasgow scrubbed up well. While The Nestrsquos location choices were more obvious ndash the Botanic Gardens, City Chambers, Kelvingrove Park ndash so far there is not a red sandstone tenement in sight.With four episodes to go, Taylorrsquos cleverly sleekit drama is shaping up nicely, playing on viewersrsquo assumptions.
